p:
Thirty-eight years after the first AIDS case was described, HIV-1 remains a major public health problem that affects approximately 36.7 (30.8–42.9) million people globally
1, 2 . Sub-Saharan Africa accounts for approximately 70% of all infections. In addition, HIV-1 represent one of the most fast-evolving pathogens known to science. This has led to the classification of HIV-1 into subtypes, sub-subtypes and circulating recombinant forms (CRFs). Of relevance, previous reports have suggested that the genetic composition of the infecting HIV-1 strain may influence transmission, disease progression, virus-host interactions, antiretroviral treatment responses, and vaccine development
3– 12 . Moreover, it has been suggested that targeted HIV-1 prevention may be a cost-effective way to decrease the number of new HIV-1 infections – not least in low-and-middle-income countries
13 . Planning of such HIV-1 intervention programs will require detailed information about both the characteristics and sources of new infections.
